div.p: Module 2, Identifying
Sustainability Opportunities.
In Module 2, we will look at
energy and facility managers'
typical tasks and responsibilities

and how to broaden them to
achieve multiple benefits
with a single action.
We will review the cyclical process
of implementing sustainability,
and ways to use decision points as bridges
to sustainable strategies.

The process for integrating
sustainability measures
into strategic goals
can generally be summarized in four steps.

Evaluate current requirements
and opportunities;
engage a team and operational performance;

develop, evaluate, and implement
sustainability measures;
revisit and revise goals and activities.

These steps outline a cycle
that should be followed

to ensure that consistent
improvements are being made.

Now let's take a look at the
first step in more detail.

The process of evaluating
current requirements

and opportunities begins by
developing an understanding

of a facility's
sustainability requirements.

Once an understanding
has been established,

the facility team could proceed
to identify opportunities
to expand sustainability efforts.
Meeting broad based sustainability goals

may or may not be part of
your formal job description
and job performance criteria.

If not, you can still
advance sustainability
by taking advantage of key opportunities
in the tasks you already perform

to include broader
sustainability measures.

Common opportunities to
incorporate sustainability
in your decision making include

undergoing a renovation or
upgrade, revising O&M contracts,
replacing inefficient or aging equipment,

schedule preventive O&M,
repurposing of office space.
Let's go over some examples
to see how these decision points

can affect the overall
sustainability of a building.
Undergoing a renovation or addition
offers many opportunities for integrating

and bundling low-cost
sustainability measures.

A common example is the
construction of a new parking lot.

After an initial assessment,
your team might identify
multiple opportunities to improve
the project's sustainability quotient
such as including clauses in the RFP
that require recycled content concrete,
requiring highly efficient lighting,
and including requirements
for electrical vehicle charging stations.
In addition to meeting the needs
of your facility's growing workforce,

these measures will have other
short and long-term impacts

such as reducing waste by using
recycled content products;
improving worker safety
with better, more efficient lighting;

and encouraging the purchase
and use of electric vehicles.

Revising O&M contracts
is a great opportunity
to improve sustainability.

A common example is the
development of an RFP

for a new contractor to
clean your facilities.
This task presents several opportunities

to add sustainability requirements
such as including clauses

that require bio-based,
non-toxic cleaning products;

incorporating sustainability
performance metrics
into vendor subcontracts;
requiring ENERGY STAR-designated products;

and using local labor
and small businesses.
The impacts of this decision
are improving indoor environmental quality

and improving workforce
health and job satisfaction.
A common equipment replacement project

is the replacing of the
heating, ventilation,

and air conditioning
system, also known as HVAC.

The opportunities related
to taking on such a project

include potential to
downsize the new HVAC system
based on calculated cost savings
from improving the building envelope;

potential to use dual heating
and cooling technologies;
commissioning the new system
and integrating existing systems
for improved energy performance;

and consider running
systems using clean energy.

The decision point can
affect sustainability
in the following ways.
Improving the energy efficiency
and energy use intensity of the building,

improving ventilation
and indoor air quality,

increasing occupant
comfort and productivity,

and reducing the need for
HAVAC repairs and downtime.

Your facility's preventive
maintenance routine
offers many opportunities
to identify sustainability improvements.
Consider the following opportunities
when performing commissioning activities

for the HVAC and building
automation systems.
Select a commissioning contractor

with sustainability
credentials and experience;

adjust building automation systems
to reflect actual occupancy;

establish an energy baseline
and develop a benchmark

to track progress; develop
energy conservation measures
based on these results.

Performing commissioning
activities on the HVAC
and building automation systems

can improve occupant comfort
during occupied office hours,

reduce manual overrides of
the building automation system
which improves energy efficiency,
improve worker health and safety,
and reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

Repurposing office space
offers many opportunities
for sustainable upgrades.
For instance, if your team is charged

with repurposing a floor
in an office building,

you should evaluate the benefits
of recycling old furniture
and building materials;

selecting new materials
and furniture that is made

from recycled content, bio-based,
and has low VOC finishes;

selecting partitions
with reflective surfaces
and lower heights to improve electric
and day lighting potentials;

purchasing and installing
efficient task lighting;

and selecting low VOC,
non-toxic, bio-based paints.
These measures can have a big impact
both in terms of reducing energy use

and improving indoor
environmental conditions
for employees.

The related impacts
are improved indoor air

and environmental quality,
improved lighting efficiency,
and improved plug loads.
In Module 2,

we reviewed the typical
tasks and responsibilities
and how they can be broadened
to include a sustainability component,
we introduced the four-step process

for integrating sustainability
into a strategic plan,

we covered key decision
points in job tasks

that can expand
sustainability opportunities.
In the next module,

we'll cover ways to
benchmark your efforts,
use software tools to chart your progress,

and ways to engage your
team in institutional change
towards sustainable operations.
